snippet: American and British spies have infiltrated online fantasy games, fearing that militants could use them to communicate, move money or plot attacks, documents show.
abstract: Documents show that American and British spies have infiltrated online fantasy games World of Warcraft and Second Life, conducting surveillance and scooping up data from millions of players; intelligence operatives fear militants could use them to communicate, move money or plot attacks; classified data was disclosed by former National Security Agency contractor Edward J Snowden.

byline.original: By MARK MAZZETTI and JUSTIN ELLIOTT
byline.contributor: Justin Elliott is a reporter for ProPublica. Andrew W. Lehren contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: American and British spies have infiltrated online fantasy games, fearing that militants could use them to communicate, move money or plot attacks, documents show.

headline.main: Spies Infiltrate a Fantasy Realm of Online Games
headline.print_headline: Spies Infiltrate a Fantasy Realm of Online Games
